title: AMP years cast shadow over Dunn on Telstra board
text:
The vote is among a string of controversial resolutions for Telstra, which has received backing for its remuneration report this year after a massive 62 per cent rejection vote last year.

Mr Dunn, who has been on Telstra's board since April 2016 and is chairman of its audit and risk committee, was chief executive of AMP between 2008 and 2013. He was previously the head of AMP's financial services division during a 13-year career at the financial services group.

While the royal commission's 2018 final report found that AMP had charged customers fees for no service between 2008 and 2015 and criticised its audit practices, Mr Dunn was not personally found liable for any misconduct.

CGI said Mr Dunn's time running AMP's financial services division before 2008 “would have afforded him significant insight” into its financial advice business while he was the company's CEO.

CGI also last year recommended against Mr Dunn's re-election to the Westpac board, which he joined in June 2015. Some 35 per cent of Westpac shareholders subsequently voted against his re-election.

'Qualified support'

But Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) has given “qualified support” for Mr Dunn's re-election to the Telstra board, arguing it was not clear whether AMP's misconduct occurred under his watch.

The Australian Shareholders Association (ASA), which represents retail investors, has also backed Mr Dunn's re-election.

Advertisement

ASA guidelines require consideration of whether a CEO “had been demonstrably responsible for key decisions which have led to poor performance over a sustained period”.

“We do not consider that this link has been demonstrated,” the ASA said. The organisation also noted Telstra had been transparent about Mr Dunn’s resume.

But the Australian Council of Superannuation Investors is against another term for Mr Dunn.

“The performance of AMP over the past decade, and the royal commission process, have highlighted the poor outcomes AMP delivered to shareholders and many customers,” ACSI said.

That included AMP’s share price being 20 per cent lower when he finished than when he started “during the middle of the GFC”, ACSI said. The council also noted AMP had started reviewing advice dating back to 2008, and associated provisions were most recently priced at $670 million.

Still, ACSI said Telstra representatives had maintained Mr Dunn “was no longer at AMP ‘long before’ issues arose and no evidence has been raised indicating his culpability”.

“Furthermore, the board discussed the matter with Mr Dunn who was open, transparent and reflective, commenting that they would not support board members if they felt they would cause disrepute or embarrassment to Telstra,” ACSI said.

Directors up for re-election under ordinary resolutions need more than 50 per cent of votes to be cast in their favour to continue sitting on a board.

Advertisement

Telstra has this year garnered support for its remuneration report, potentially avoiding a second “strike” against pay. That is when more than 25 per cent of votes are against the remuneration report two years in a row, triggering a board spill.

Advisory groups including CGI, ISS and the ASA have supported Telstra's new pay scheme. ACSI said reforms included reducing maximum potential pay by 20 per cent for chief executive Andy Penn and 13 per cent for other executives.

Telstra also issued one of the “best examples of disclosure” around bonuses of any ASX-listed entity, ACSI said. The telecommunications company disclosed its bonus scorecard and targets as the year started.

But ACSI detailed governance concerns about “accounting risk” given the jump in use of “reverse factoring”, in which companies use a financier to quickly pay supplier bills.

The suppliers will be paid earlier by the financier if they take a discount on the total amount due. The system helps the billed company lengthen and smooth out its own cash flows.

“Telstra’s cash flow received a significant benefit from extending payment terms for its suppliers – from a disclosed maximum of 45 to 90 days – in conjunction with a rapid increase in the use of ‘reverse factoring’ arrangements,” ACSI said.
description: The banking royal commission fallout continues with shareholder advisers split over re-electing Craig Dunn as a Telstra director.
